description: A calque of Latin locus commūnis, referring to a generally applicable literary passage, itself a calque of Ancient Greek κοινὸς τόπος (koinòs tópos).

adjectives.description: commonplace (comparative more commonplace, superlative most commonplace)

entries.meaning: Ordinary; not having any remarkable characteristics.
examples: Synonyms: routine, undistinguished, unexceptional; see also Thesaurus:hackneyed

entries.meaning: Something that is ordinary; something commonly done or occurring.
A memorandum; something to be frequently consulted or referred to.
examples: Whatever, in my reading, occurs concerning this our fellow creature, I do never fail to set it down by way of common-place.

verbs.description: commonplace (third-person singular simple present commonplaces, present participle commonplacing, simple past and past participle commonplaced)

entries.meaning: To enter in a commonplace book, or to reduce to general heads.
examples: I do not apprehend any difficulty in collecting and commonplacing an universal history from the  […] historians.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To utter commonplaces; to indulge in platitudes.
examples: For the good that comes of particular and select committees and commissions, I need not commonplace.
